awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Acoustic monitoring of remote pumping equipment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this acoustic monitoring technology for remote pumping equipment is to help ensure the reliable and continuous flow of critical products, such as public water or oil and gas while increasing societal well-being and reducing industrial carbon footprint.  The initial focus will be on equipment such as compressors, valves or pumps located in a remote or dangerous location. This novel acoustic method and the corresponding AI analytics brings novel and advanced functionalities at a fraction of the cost of existing methods. This allows users such as water companies or oil producers to reduce the energy needs of their equipment while reducing downtime and enabling early detection of many types of failures.

This I-Corps project further develops an acoustic monitoring platform for remote pumping equipment.  It is a full stack internet of things solution for the monitoring, diagnostic and control of industrial equipment. Acoustic monitoring is a novel method that uses sensors to detect complex issues in remote pumping equipment. Simple surface sensors give important insight on the running condition of underground or remote equipment by integrating acoustic sensing with AI analytics. A control solution then adjusts the running condition of the equipment to extend its lifetime and increase its efficiency. The proposed industrial control solution aims to reduce down time, decrease leakage and increase the efficiency and output of many industrial pumps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps award provided the framework and training to understand the potential applications, customers and key value propositions of a new technology that can have global impact on energy consumption by users such as water companies or oil producers while improving the uptime efficiency of the equipment by providing early detection of potential problems and failures using our acoustic monitoring and AI.

During the initial 7 week training, the team conducted an intensive customer discovery and interview process accomplishing more than 100 interviews with potential customers. This process was continued after the conclusion of the national cohort with a greta many more customer interviews for discovery and validation. Through this process, we identified customer segments and subsegments, discovery of several pivots necessary to target these segments, and identification of a value proposition for these customer segments.  

This led to the formation of a startup, Acoustic Wells, Inc., to commercialize this acoustic monitoring technology for remote pumping equipment. By the end of this award, the startup employed 12 full-time and part-time engineers and raised over $2.2 million in additional grants and venture capital investments.

The company has reached successful commercialization and is shipping products with a beachhead market focus in the oil industry. By providing an affordable solution for asset and condition monitoring, we hope to gather data on assets that have never been regularly monitored previously. We believe this data has great value both in active asset optimization, but also driving industry-wide knowledge to better understand failures and their causes. Additionally, we have already detected several methane leaks on a few facilities. The company is on its way to bring advanced manufacturing technologies to the US upstream oil & gas industry, fostering US energy independence and reducing its carbon footprint. 

The technology developed as a result of this project has many potential applications in the industrial space. We are currently focused on the oil and gas industry, specifically on monitoring and controlling oil pumps as well as detecting methane leaks. However, we plan to expand to city utilities, including gas and water systems, as well as high pressure industrial hydraulic systems and compressor systems. Using our technology, we can make pumps and compressors more reliable and energy efficient while also detecting any leaks or other failure cases.  We believe that applying AI on the edge on small low power microcontrollers is an important breakthrough that can be used in many industrial applications.  Our IoT platform can also be used to monitor distributed assets such as power lines, wind farms and transformers.

This project has helped connect and educate small businesses, mostly in rural America, about new technologies such as IoT and AI. It is helping update the way they work, changing their processes from tedious manual activities to automatic web-based monitoring and control. We are aiming to improve their quality of life by helping them work smarter and more efficiently, as well as avoid accident risk by eliminating many unnecessary manual processes.


Last Modified: 06/20/2022
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
